## Definition

- Mole = mass equivalent of the molar mass of a molecule

::: {.fragment}
![](./O_C_O.png){.absolute top="17.5%" left="25%" width="55%"}
:::

::: {.fragment .absolute top=37.5% left=30%}
molar mass $\mathrm{CO_2}$: $44.010$
:::

::: {.fragment .absolute top=45% left=0%}
 gram-mol equivalent $\swarrow$
:::

::: {style="font-size: 95px;"}
::: {.fragment .absolute top=52.5% left=0%}
1 gram-mol $\mathrm{CO_2} \rightarrow$ 44.010 grams
:::
:::

::: {.fragment .absolute top=45% right=0%}
$\searrow$ lb-mol equivalent
:::

::: {style="font-size: 95px;"}
::: {.fragment .absolute top=52.5% right=0%}
1 lb-mol $\mathrm{CO_2} \rightarrow$ 44.010 $\mathrm{lb_m}$
:::
:::

## How many different types of moles are there?

- 15 mass units on N.I.S.T website $\rightarrow$ at least 15 types of moles
- range: carat-mole â€” pennyweight-mole
- Most common moles are:
  - $\text{g-mol}$ or $\text{mole}$
  - $\text{kg-mol}$ or $\text{kilomole}$
  - $\text{metric-ton-mole}$ or $\text{tonne-mole}$
  - $\text{lb-mol}$
  - $\text{ton-mole}$

:::{.fragment .absolute top=26% right=15%}

:::


## Use the Correct Moles

- Unless the problem is in grams, don't use gram moles!
- ***Inefficient*** steps for using gram moles:
  - Start with mass in units other than grams.
    1. Convert to grams.
    2. Convert to gram-moles.
    3. Use balanced chemical equation to solve for the other species in gram-moles.
    4. Convert the other species' gram-moles to grams.
    5. Convert the grams to the starting mass species.
- Requires five steps.

## Use the Correct Moles

- Unless the problem is in grams, don't use gram moles!
- Efficient steps for using moles:
  - Start with mass in units other than grams.
    1. Convert to  the mass unit's moles.
    2. Use balanced chemical equation to solve for the other species in the mass unit's moles.
    3. Convert the other species' moles to mass units.
- Requires three steps instead of five.
- 40% fewer places to make mistakes!


## The Takeaways

1. Different types of moles are for different types of mass units.
2. The molar mass is just the conversion factor between moles and mass. It has the same numerical value for all mass/mole pairs.
3. Use gram moles for problems in grams. Use pound-moles for problems in pounds, etc.
